description: From Middle English *slammen (not recorded), apparently from a Scandinavian source ultimately from Old Norse slæma, slœma (“to slam, swing a weapon, strike an object out of reach”), related to Old Norse slamra, slambra (“to slam”). Cognate with Norwegian Bokmål slamre (“to slam”), Swedish slamra (“to pound, beat, make a clatter, rattle”), Norwegian Nynorsk slamra (“to sway, dangle”).

entries.meaning: (countable) A sudden impact or blow.
examples: How many slams in an old screen door? / Depends how loud you shut it.

entries.meaning: (countable) The shock and noise produced by violently closing a door or other object.
(countable, basketball) A slam dunk.
(countable, tennis) One of the competitions of the yearly Grand Slam events.
(countable, colloquial, US) An insult.
examples: I don't mean this as a slam, but you can be really impatient sometimes.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, UK, dialect) The yellow iron silicate produced in alum works as a waste product.
A poetry slam.
A slambook.
examples: Regular friendship books had a variety of variations, such as slams, crams, and decos.

entries.meaning: (music, uncountable) A subgenre of death metal with elements of hardcore punk focusing on midtempo rhythms, breakdowns and palm-muted riffs

verbs.description: slam (third-person singular simple present slams, present participle slamming, simple past and past participle slammed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, ergative) To shut with sudden force so as to produce a shock and noise.
(transitive, ergative) To put in or on a particular place with force and loud noise. (Often followed by a preposition such as down, against or into.)
examples: Don't slam that trunk down on the pavement!

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To strike forcefully with some implement.
(intransitive) To strike against suddenly and heavily.
examples: The boat slammed into the bank and we were almost thrown into the river.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To strike and take the life of or at least incapacitate for some time.
(transitive, sports slang) To defeat or overcome in a match.
examples: The Armenian football team has slammed the Turks 6–0.

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To speak badly of; to criticize forcefully.
examples: Don't ever slam me in front of the boss like that again!
Union leaders slammed the new proposals.
Critics slammed the new film, calling it violent and meaningless.

entries.meaning: To compete in a poetry slam.
(basketball) To dunk forcefully, to slam dunk.
(transitive, telecommunications) To move a customer from one service provider to another without their consent.
(transitive) To drink off, to drink quickly.
(transitive, drugs, slang) To inject intravenously; shoot up.
(transitive, sex, slang, vulgar) To perform coitus upon forcefully; to rail.
(informal, US) To occupy and busy with a high workload.
(uncountable, obsolete) A type of card game, also called ruff and honours.
A card game, played all at once without separate turns, in which players attempt to get rid of their cards as quickly as possible according to certain rules.
(countable, card games) Losing or winning all the tricks in a game.
(countable, bridge) A bid of six (small slam) or seven (grand slam) in a suit or no trump.
(countable, sports) Winning all (or all but one) of the available, major or specified events in a given year or sports season.

verbs.description: slam (third-person singular simple present slams, present participle slamming, simple past and past participle slammed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, card games) To defeat (opponents at cards) by winning all the tricks of a deal or a hand.
examples: D having seven Spades in his Hand wins them, and consequently slams A and B

entries.meaning: (intransitive, bridge) To make a slam bid.
(obsolete) A shambling fellow.
